title: Are we getting more allergic to things?
intro: Do you know anyone who has 50 allergies? Neil and Beth discuss this and teach you some new vocabulary.
this_week_question: What is the most common allergy in the world?
a)    Peanuts? b)    Pollen? c)    Dairy?
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: phone before an appointment, or before going somewhere
strict rules for how something is done
(allergy)  a place that is known for (allergies)
used to indicate that a number is an estimate, or is not exact

transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. In this episode, we're talking about allergies. Allergies are when a certain food or material makes you feel sick. Do you have any allergies, Beth?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I'm not great with dairy either, but it's not an allergy – more of an intolerance. So, it just makes me feel a bit bad rather than actually making me sick. I get runny eyes and a runny nose, and it also gives me a little bit of asthma, so it's a bit of a pain.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Oh yeah, that sounds really horrible. Now, scientific evidence shows that more people are developing allergies. In this programme we're going to find out about what it's like living with an allergy and where in the world has the highest rate of allergies.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But first, I have a question for you, Beth. What is the most common allergy in the world? Is it:

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: I'm going to say pollen. A lot of people I know have hay fever.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Including me. Well, we'll find out the answer at the end of the show. Now, Beth, you're allergic to dairy, but imagine if you had over 50 allergies. That's the situation for Mia Silverman, who runs a social media account, Allergies with Mia, where she talks about living with lots of allergies.

transcript.author: Mia Silverman
transcript.text: My 50+ allergies include all nuts and their oils. I'm allergic to all fish except for cooked tuna and cooked codfish.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Life for Mia involves a lot of planning, as she told BBC World Service programme, What in the World.

transcript.author: Mia Silverman
transcript.text: And having these 50+ allergies impacts my life every single day. When it comes to socialising, it can be kind of hard sometimes, because I want to make sure that my friends don't feel inconvenienced or feel like I'm being a burden.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: If Mia wants to go to a restaurant, she has to call ahead of time to tell them about her allergies. If you call ahead of time , you phone somewhere, like a restaurant before you go. We can also say call ahead .

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Mia needs to find out whether restaurants can accommodate her allergies. Accommodate in this context means give someone what they need.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Because Mia has so many allergies, she has to visit restaurants which have protocols to stop the food she is allergic to touching her meal. Protocols means a set of rules for a process, to make sure things are done properly.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Now, most people who have allergies don't have as many as Mia, but scientists believe more people are developing allergies. And there is one place where the number of allergies is particularly high: Australia.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In fact, Australia is called the allergy capital of the world . When we describe somewhere as the capital of the world in something, we mean that it is known for that thing. So, the allergy capital of the world is the place in the world with the most allergies.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: BBC journalist Frances Mao is from Australia and explains some of the allergy data to BBC World Service podcast, What in the World.

transcript.author: Interviewer
transcript.text: You're from Australia, which has been called the allergy capital of the world . What is it about Australia in particular that is making people more allergic?

transcript.author: Frances Mao
transcript.text: Australia's termed the allergy capital of the world because, due to the research and the data, that shows that almost one in 10 infants have marked an allergy. And often that's a food allergy or a respiratory allergy. And that does drop off once they're a bit older. Age six or so it goes down to about 6%, and then as an adult it goes down to like 3%.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Frances talks about the high numbers of Australian infants, that's babies, who have allergies. But she says the numbers drop off as children get older. If numbers or rates of something drop off , they get lower.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: By age six or so, Australian children are less likely to have allergies. We can use or so in informal speech to show that the number is an estimate: it's not exact.

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Beth

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Beth
